OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press said: "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. "Children have extended its [#] use from a simple prefix or as a search term for Twitter to an editorial device to add drama or comment." Other words on the technological endangered list are iPod, mp3 and Blackberry. Results from a throat swab, which measures sugars on the tongue, are provided in five minutes. The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The volcano, located 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant, is also close to Kagoshima, a city of 600,000. Sakurajima's last deadly eruption was in 1914, when 58 people died. The Japanese archipelago, which sits on the Pacific "Ring of fire", has more than 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima regularly spews ash and there are many small explosions there each year, with the latest eruption being in February. It is closely monitored by Japanese authorities and one of two volcanoes at Level 3 out of 5 levels in Japan's volcanic warning system, which means that people are warned not to to approach the volcano. "The 1914 eruption measured about 1.5km cubed in volume," said the study's lead author Dr James Hickey, who has now joined the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines. sampled: Major Richard Scott, 40, stands accused of recklessly driving his Audi A6 at speeds up to 95mph through treacherous weather conditions on a narrow B-road in Wiltshire. During a harrowing incident, Gareth Hicks, 24, suffered fatal injuries when the van in which he was sleeping was violently struck by Major Scott's vehicle. Prosecutor Charles Gabb alleged that the defendant dramatically crossed the 60mph-limit carriageway of the B390 near Shrewton during appalling weather marked by strong winds and torrential rain. Witnesses described Scott's car as "twitching" and potentially aquaplaning before initially colliding with a BMW driven by Craig Reed. The Audi then reportedly veered back to its original lane before catastrophically crossing the road again and smashing head-on into a Ford Transit van carrying Mr. Hicks, who was traveling with colleague Patrick Gilleece to a construction site in Salisbury. Major Scott, who sustained substantial injuries and claims no memory of the crash, contests the charge of causing death by careless driving, suggesting alternatively that Mr. Reed was responsible for initiating the collision. The trial is ongoing.

Palmer expects to be fined by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) for a rule breach during Champions Day. "It was an oversight," Palmer told BBC Sport. "The wrong kit box was left in the lorry and taken to the stables." The Newmarket-based trainer saw Galileo Gold finish fifth in the Group One Queen Elizabeth II Stakes at Ascot. Horses are only allowed to receive hay-feed or water before a race, but other substances such as electrolytes are permitted post-race. Employees of Palmer and fellow trainers, Francois Rohaut and Jean-Claude Rouget, as well as the trainers themselves, were interviewed by stewards following a report by the Equine Welfare and Integrity Officer. Palmer is yet to hear what punishment the BHA will hand down. "I imagine there will be a routine fine for a rule that's been broken," he told BBC Radio Berkshire. "There's no suggestion that anyone was trying to seek an advantage or cheat. It's simply what the rule says. The rules are the rules and you need to stick to them." BHA media spokesman Robin Mounsey said: "Of the substances, three are electrolytes which are permitted in the stables but they just failed to clear it beforehand, while the other substance is permitted in training but just not on a race day." All the horses involved, Signs Of Blessing, Architecture, Galileo Gold, and Almanzor - winner of the Champion Stakes - were routine tested. Meanwhile, Palmer has confirmed Galileo Gold will race on next season and the four-year-old will stay in training. "Horses like him are incredibly hard to find," he added. "When you find them, you want to try and keep them."

In the hallowed halls of Merthyr Tydfil College, Regina Hungerford, a seasoned educator of 56 years, found herself ensnared in a tempestuous encounter with a recalcitrant teenage student. Vehemently denying any physical transgression while the youth immersed himself in rap music, Hungerford faced a disciplinary tribunal that ultimately concluded physical contact was probable. Though she passionately proclaimed her innocence, the panel deemed her conduct unacceptable, a verdict that threatened to unravel her lifelong pedagogical passion. Stripped of her professional standing for a mere four months and mandated to undertake a comportment rehabilitation course, Hungerford's fate hung in a delicate balance. The panel, led by Gareth Roberts, ultimately determined that the broader educational interests would be served by allowing her eventual return to the classroom, recognizing the nuanced complexities of an incident that had cast a long shadow over her distinguished career.

She was speaking at a somber event on Thursday to commemorate four men who were fatally shot by the SAS in her home village of Clonoe in 1992. DUP leader Arlene Foster criticized Mrs O'Neill's attendance, but her stance was unsurprising. Mrs O'Neill staunchly defended her decision to speak at the memorial. The four IRA men were killed after launching an attack on Coalisland police station. Soldiers opened fire on them as they abandoned a lorry used in the machine-gun assault in February 1992. An Alliance Party spokesperson emphasized the importance of focusing on healing and reconciliation. "While people will naturally want to mark those who died during the Troubles, it is crucial to prioritize healing wounds and avoid glamorizing violence." SDLP justice spokesperson Alex Attwood highlighted the ongoing challenges, noting, "The fundamental roadblock to justice, truth, and accountability is the insistence of some to address the past on their own terms, rather than those required by victims and survivors."

Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) delivered a stark assessment of Bedfordshire Police, characterizing its staffing levels as "fragile" and urgently calling for rapid improvement plans. Following a critical evaluation of the force's response to government spending cuts, inspectors returned in October to find performance lagging behind comparable regional forces. The report pinpointed challenges within the force control room, though noting potential improvements from recent staff increases. While acknowledging some positive momentum, inspectors expressed concern about the force's long-term strategic approach and ability to reduce operational demand effectively. Police and Crime Commissioner Olly Martins challenged the report's relevance, arguing that publishing outdated assessments could potentially undermine police morale and mislead the public. HMIC defended its methodology, indicating further assessments were planned in March, May, and July to comprehensively track the force's progress and development.

Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The UNESCO World Heritage Site comprises approximately 40,000 expansive black basalt columns protruding from the sea. It was the Royal couple's inaugural visit to Northern Ireland's most renowned tourist attraction. The causeway formed when molten rock was forced through terrestrial fissures, creating a lava plateau. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh subsequently travelled to the nearby village of Bushmills to commemorate local soldier Robert Quigg. He was awarded the Victoria Cross for exceptional bravery during the Battle of the Somme, having ventured into the line of fire to search for his commanding officer. The Royal couple unveiled a statue and commemorative stone, with his grandnephew, Leonard Quigg, delivering a brief address. Subsequently, they attended a reception at Portrush Golf Club, hosted by the mayor of the Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council. Thereafter, they embarked on a nostalgic journey aboard a steam train from Coleraine, County Londonderry, to Bellarena. Substantial crowds gathered in Coleraine to welcome the couple as they boarded the five-carriage train, constructed in 1932. Accompanied by local schoolchildren, they travelled to Bellarena, where the Queen officially inaugurated the village's new train station. The Royal guests first traversed this historic railway line in 1953, the year of her coronation, when the original station had been operational for a century. Following recent infrastructure improvements, the Queen unveiled a plaque marking the new development, while wellwishers lined the route, waving union flags and offering enthusiastic greetings. On Monday, the Royal visitor met Northern Ireland's first and deputy first ministers at Hillsborough Castle in County Down. This visit constituted the third high-profile royal engagement in recent weeks, following appearances by the Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh's most recent prior visit to Northern Ireland was in June 2014.

The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) revealed a stark contrast in child development between London and the north of England. Their report, launched in Sheffield, highlighted that only 47% of children from the poorest families in the north achieved a good level of early years development, compared to 59% in London. Despite this challenge, the survey found that northern city-regions boast nearly as many well-qualified individuals as London, with 3.6 million compared to London's 3.7 million. The IPPR proposed 11 benchmarks for the Northern Powerhouse initiative, emphasizing the need to close the developmental gap for children under five. IPPR's director Ed Cox passionately argued that transforming the region requires a generational investment in human capital, focusing on education and training from the earliest stages. "We will never become a powerhouse economy when our children and young people have such a poor start in life," Cox stated. He stressed the importance of devolving economic powers across the North to support productive, resilient growth and create opportunities for all. The government acknowledged the challenge, committing additional funds to early years providers and noting that 250,000 more pupils in the north now attend good or outstanding schools since 2010.

Seamer Abbott, 29, and top-order batsman Rossouw, 27, confirmed their international retirements in January. Rossouw, in his first season of county cricket, was guarded about the circumstances of his departure. "Maybe, maybe not," he told BBC Sport. "I think that story is one I'm going to tell at a different time." Kolpak contracts allow sportsmen from countries with associate trade agreements with the European Union to be afforded the same right to free movement as EU citizens. Under these contracts, they are not classified as overseas players but become ineligible to represent their country at international level. Abbott and Rossouw's decisions came before Britain's exit from the European Union, and they are among several South Africans to make the switch ahead of the new domestic season. Other players include all-rounder Simon Harmer joining Essex, Stiaan van Zyl and David Wiese moving to Sussex, and fast bowler Hardus Viljoen signing with Derbyshire. "Right now, I'm just going to enjoy life here in England," Rossouw said, preparing to start a three-year contract with Hampshire. "I'm enthusiastic about the season. I'm 100% clear on my decision and don't think that's going to change any time soon. Right now, my home is in England and I want to be here beyond the next three years." For Abbott, a four-year deal marks a return to the county he last played for as an overseas signing in 2014. "I made a lot of friends here during my last spell and it just felt like the right place for me," the right-arm pace bowler said. Abbott broke down in tears when he announced his international retirement after helping South Africa to a home series win against Sri Lanka, but said at Hampshire's pre-season media day that he had come to terms with his reasons for doing so long before it was confirmed. "I've been comfortable for a long time to be honest," he added. "I've always felt like Hampshire was a home for me. It was a pretty easy transition across here." Abbott and Rossouw will hope to make immediate impressions for Hampshire when they begin their County Championship Division One campaign against Yorkshire on 7 April.

The launch of what was supposed to be its flagship model has turned into a fiasco for the world's largest smartphone maker. As the South Korean company scrambles to contain the crisis, we look back at the developments so far: On 2 August, Samsung unveils its latest Galaxy Note 7 in New York, packed with innovative features like an iris scanner. Initial response is positive, with high expectations of rivaling the upcoming iPhone 7. Sales begin on 19 August in 10 markets, including South Korea and the United States, with European markets scheduled for October. By 24 August, the first reports emerge of Note 7 devices "exploding," quickly followed by numerous user-generated images and videos documenting phones overheating, exploding, or catching fire. On 2 September, Samsung announces a voluntary global recall of 2.5 million phones due to faulty batteries, offering refunds or replacements. By 8 September, the US Federal Aviation Administration and airlines worldwide prohibit passengers from using or charging the device on planes. On 9 September, the US Consumer Product Safety Commission urges people to stop using the phone and issues a formal recall. Samsung resumes sales in South Korea on 1 October, with replacement efforts in full swing in the US. However, on 6 October, reports surface of replacement phones experiencing similar issues, including a Southwest Airlines flight evacuation due to a smoking device. By 9 October, US carriers AT&T and T-Mobile cease selling and issuing replacements. On 11 October, Samsung halts all sales, instructing users to power down and discontinue use of the Note 7 while investigating the problems.

The removal of 13 fire engines, which have been idle for two years, would leave 142 active vehicles in the capital. The London Fire Brigade (LFB) proposes investing the resulting savings in making more staff available to crew Fire Rescue Units. However, the Fire Brigades Union (FBU) condemned the plan as "dangerous and reckless," arguing against permanent engine removal. LFB has released three savings plans, insisting no stations will close and no firefighters will lose their jobs. The Brigade maintains that it has consistently met London-wide attendance time targets during the engines' downtime and claims reintroducing them would improve response times by approximately four seconds for the first engine to reach an emergency scene. London Assembly Member Andrew Dismore has proposed an alternative approach, recommending returning the 13 fire engines to service while achieving savings through alternate crewing at stations with specialist appliances. The proposals will be discussed on 2 December, with a full public consultation planned to explore potential savings. The FBU remains steadfast in its opposition, particularly in the wake of recent terrorist attacks, warning that further engine reductions could compromise emergency response capabilities and potentially increase response times, as demonstrated by the impact of last year's station closures.

The news agency's Twitter account was abruptly suspended after a startling false report of explosions at the White House, which momentarily sent US markets into a tailspin. The fabricated message claimed President Barack Obama had been injured, causing the Dow Jones Industrial Average to plummet 150 points before quickly rebounding. The Associated Press swiftly denounced the hack, revealing that cybercriminals had repeatedly attempted to compromise journalists' passwords. A group calling itself the Syrian Electronic Army claimed responsibility, boasting of their digital infiltration. The attack followed a sophisticated phishing email that mimicked an internal communication, tricking staff into revealing login credentials. FBI investigators began examining the incident, while AP disabled additional Twitter accounts and collaborated with the platform to probe the security breach. The hackers, who had previously targeted other major news organizations, celebrated their digital assault with a provocative tweet mocking the American president. Twitter urged users to remain vigilant, highlighting the growing threat of sophisticated cyber intrusions targeting media institutions.

The verdant landscape unfolded before John McCormack's lorry, a scene marred by his dangerous driving on the A9. The prosecutor, Rebecca Kynaston, detailed how he veered into oncoming traffic near the House of Bruar, forcing motorists to swerve onto the verge. McCormack's vehicle collided with a family car containing three children, scraping along its side with significant force. Despite the impact, he continued driving for miles before police intercepted him. At 46 years old and from Kilmarnock, McCormack admitted to dangerous driving, failing to stop after an accident, and operating a vehicle in an unsafe condition. His defense claimed he had no memory of the incident beyond a sneezing episode. Sheriff Lindsay Foulis noted the potential catastrophe, highlighting that five vehicles had to take evasive action on the main trunk road. As a result, McCormack was sentenced to 250 hours of unpaid work and received a two-year driving ban.

In a statement, Foreign Affairs Secretary Perfecto Yasay announced plans to raise the South China Sea dispute at the Asia-Europe summit, following a UN-backed tribunal's ruling that invalidated China's maritime claims. The two-day Asem summit in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, will bring together 53 leaders from Asia and Europe, marking the first major diplomatic gathering since the July 12 arbitration decision. Representing President Rodrigo Duterte's new government, Yasay will articulate the Philippines' peaceful, rules-based approach to the territorial conflict. While the previous administration celebrated the ruling as a "milestone decision," Duterte has adopted a more conciliatory stance, suggesting potential resource-sharing with China. Despite the tribunal's binding ruling that China violated the Philippines' sovereign rights and caused environmental damage, the Permanent Court of Arbitration lacks enforcement mechanisms. China has flatly rejected the ruling, declaring the summit an inappropriate forum for discussion and maintaining its territorial assertions. The summit presents a critical diplomatic opportunity for regional stakeholders to address the complex maritime tensions that have significant geopolitical implications.

In a strategic leap forward, Google Assistant transcended its Pixel-exclusive origins, promising to revolutionize smartphone interactions across Android devices. The intelligent virtual companion, reminiscent of Apple's Siri, stands poised to transform how users engage with technology, offering intuitive app navigation and instant knowledge retrieval. LG's G6 emerged as an early adopter, signaling a significant shift in the digital assistant landscape. As the update cascades through Android 6.0 Marshmallow and 7.0 Nougat devices this week, Gummi Hafsteinsson from Google envisions hundreds of millions discovering the Assistant's capabilities. The competitive arena buzzed with innovation, as Lenovo Moto and Huawei unveiled their partnerships with Amazon's Alexa, further intensifying the virtual assistant race. Google's Assistant distinguishes itself through its conversational intelligence, designed to engage users in dynamic, contextual interactions. Tech analyst Ian Fogg emphasizes the strategic brilliance: as more users interact with the Assistant, its machine learning algorithms continuously refine its cognitive capabilities. Initially launching for English-speaking users in the United States, with subsequent rollouts in Australia, Canada, and the United Kingdom, Google's vision of an adaptive, intelligent digital companion begins to take shape.

The election commission (Inec) anticipated announcing the winner on Monday, despite significant challenges. The UN commended the poll, acknowledging technical difficulties, protests, and Boko Haram-related violence. Voting extended into a second day in parts of Nigeria due to problems with new electronic card readers, which even prevented President Jonathan from casting his ballot. The Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) decried the technology as a "huge national embarrassment," while Inec chair Attahiru Jega emphasized that only a small fraction of the 150,000 card readers nationwide had malfunctioned. The election, delayed six weeks by Boko Haram's insurgency, saw militants attacking polling stations in north-eastern states, prompting a curfew in Bauchi State after confrontations with security forces. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon praised Nigerian voters' determination, describing the process as "largely peaceful and orderly," a sentiment echoed by Ecowas, which urged national acceptance of the results. However, tensions persisted in Rivers State, where thousands protested alleged opposition worker killings and voting irregularities, with Inec reporting an office was burned during the unrest. While results were expected to emerge Sunday night, no clear party lead had been established, marking a potentially pivotal moment as the long-dominant PDP faced a serious challenge from Gen Buhari's All Progressives Congress, with voters simultaneously electing representatives to the house and senate.

In the somber embrace of the Southern Uplands, a tragic tale unfolded as Geoffrey Stewart, 74, of Dumfries, and his companions—George Crosbie, 73, and Bobby Thomson, 64—ventured into the treacherous hills of Durisdeer. Their familiar terrain transformed into a merciless landscape, where relentless rain, swirling snow, and howling winds conspired against their journey. Despite the valiant efforts of sixteen Moffat Mountain Rescue team members and two search dogs who combed the rugged terrain through the night, the harsh elements ultimately claimed two lives. Mr. Stewart and Mr. Crosbie succumbed to the unforgiving wilderness, with Thomson surviving to bear witness to their final expedition. A poignant statement from Stewart's family honored the rescuers and fellow mourners, acknowledging the profound loss and expressing gratitude for the heroic rescue efforts. These experienced walkers, longtime explorers of the Lowther Hills, met their fate in the very landscape they had long traversed, a stark reminder of nature's unpredictable and unforgiving spirit.

In a dynamic labor market landscape, unemployment dipped to 1.69 million between January and March, marking a subtle decline of 2,000 from the previous quarter. The jobless rate held steady at 5.1%, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). Employment surged to a historic peak of 74.2%, with 31.58 million individuals in work, representing a modest 44,000 increase. However, job vacancies experienced a notable contraction, dropping 18,000 to 745,000—the first such decline in nearly a year.

The earnings front revealed nuanced shifts, with average wages, including bonuses, rising 2% year-on-year, marginally up from 1.9%. Excluding bonuses, earnings grew 2.1%, signaling a subtle moderation. The number of jobless benefit claimants decreased by 2,400 in April to 737,800, though revised data highlighted a significant increase between February and March.

Government officials celebrated the milestone, with Secretary of State Stephen Crabb hailing record-breaking employment figures. Economists, however, offered a more tempered perspective, noting potential signs of economic deceleration and suggesting the jobs recovery might be losing momentum. Martin Beck of the EY Item Club cautioned against expecting the rapid unemployment drops witnessed in 2015 to persist indefinitely.

Taibu, a 32-year-old former Zimbabwe international who played 28 Test matches and 150 one-day internationals before retiring in 2012, has signed with Hightown St Mary's. Hightown's publicity officer Nick Gordon initially suspected a hoax but verified Taibu's credentials through references from Zimbabwe cricket circles. The wicketkeeper-batsman is set to debut against Alder on 24 April, having approached the club after they advertised for an overseas player.

Gordon emphasized the extraordinary nature of the signing, noting that a retired Test cricketer joining a Second Division side is unprecedented. Despite Taibu's extended absence from competitive cricket, the club believes his international experience will significantly elevate their summer performance. The signing has generated considerable excitement and disbelief among Hightown's players and rival teams.

"It's not every day that club-level players get to compete against an international Test captain," Gordon remarked. The prospect of amateur cricketers facing a seasoned professional has created a buzz, with social media already abuzz with speculation about how Hightown secured such a remarkable recruit. This unexpected transfer promises to inject fresh excitement into local cricket, bridging the gap between professional and amateur levels.

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, translating to "fuel shortage in a film", became France's top Twitter trend on Tuesday, with over 5,000 tweets. A strike over new labour laws is affecting all eight of France's oil refineries, with an estimated 20% of petrol stations running dry or low on supplies. French social media users creatively reimagined film titles to reflect the shortage, renaming classics like Pulp Fiction to "Pump Friction" and Mad Max: Fury Road to "Mad Max: Bicycle Lane". Vin Diesel's Fast and Furious franchise inspired variations such as "Last and Furious" and "Pas Fast Mais Furious", while other films like 8 Mile became "0 Mile" and "8 Miles a Pied". Kubrick's works weren't spared, with Full Metal Jacket transformed to "Fuel Metal Jacket" and references to Renault's Espace minivan. Users also playfully incorporated jerrycans into titles like "Tom and Jerrycan" and "Catch Me If You Jerrycan", with Drive becoming "Walk and Drive Pas". The creative wordplay highlighted the widespread impact of the fuel shortage on French daily life.

Among them was a vulnerable 17-year-old intercepted at Sydney airport, a chilling testament to the seductive power of extremist ideologies, according to Immigration Minister Peter Dutton. Mr. Dutton warned of the haunting, ever-growing threat of young Australians being lured into the dark embrace of groups like Islamic State (IS). Special anti-terror teams, now vigilantly stationed at Australia's eight international airports since August, represent a desperate shield against this insidious recruitment. The intercepted teenager, on the precipice of being drawn into the Middle East's savage conflict, was returned to his parents' trembling custody while investigations delved into his troubled path. Just days earlier, two Sydney brothers—mere teenagers themselves—were stopped at the same airport, their youthful dreams hijacked by radical propaganda. Despite the school's cautious reinstatement, whispers of unease lingered among concerned parents. Australia's anti-terrorism units have already engaged with 85,000 individuals, a staggering number that underscores the pervasive threat. With approximately 90 citizens having already vanished into Iraq and Syria's treacherous landscapes, and 20 tragically lost to the conflict, the nation grapples with a heartbreaking reality. The story of Jake Bilardi, a Melbourne teenager reportedly transformed into a suicide attacker, epitomizes this devastating journey—a lonely soul manipulated into becoming what his father described as a "trophy" paraded by IS, a chilling symbol of vulnerability exploited. The law stands resolute: any Australian stepping into IS strongholds without legitimate cause faces a potential decade behind bars, a stark deterrent against radicalization's seductive call.

The amnesty applies to offences committed during the political turmoil following Mr. Thaksin's ousting in a coup. The lower house passed the controversial bill in the early hours of Friday, with the bill advancing to the Senate. The opposition Democrat Party has cautioned that the bill's passage will likely incite street protests. Despite the party's abstention, the bill passed unanimously with 310 votes. The bill's passage through the Senate remains uncertain, as half its members are appointed, though it could potentially occur as early as next week, which would likely provoke further demonstrations. Advocates argue the bill will resolve the political divisions stemming from the 2006 military coup that removed Mr. Thaksin from power, a period marked by significant unrest including the occupation of Bangkok's main airport in 2008 and two months of protests in 2010 that resulted in approximately 90 casualties, predominantly civilian protesters. Critics, however, contend the amnesty would effectively shield human rights abuses from accountability. Human Rights Watch's Asia director, Brad Adams, emphasized that the proposed legislation would allow officials and protest leaders responsible for violence to evade justice. The opposition believes the bill is strategically designed to facilitate Mr. Thaksin's return without imprisonment, as he has remained in self-imposed exile since his 2008 corruption conviction. Initially limited to ordinary protesters, the amnesty was unexpectedly expanded to include individuals investigated by post-coup agencies. The bill's potential passage has sparked significant political tension, with the Democrat Party pledging continued opposition through street protests and potential legal challenges, including a petition to the Constitutional Court.

Over the next few years, Forest Enterprise Scotland will plant acorns around Loch Trool and the Cree Valley, aiming to grow approximately 600,000 young trees and create a large, vibrant habitat. Environment forester Gareth Ventress explained that upon discovering a bumper crop of acorns, they initiated a comprehensive collection strategy, enlisting staff from across Scotland to gather acorns from native oak woods on the national forest estate. The Cree Valley Community Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust, and Moffat Community Woodlands collaborated in this extensive collection effort to expand native woodland across southern Scotland.

By combining acorns from Galloway Forest Park, they aim to enhance genetic diversity, linking remnant woodlands and creating robust, disease-resistant forests for the future. The collection process involves laying large felt nets across the forest floor to facilitate easier gathering and prevent soil contamination. After collection, acorns are carefully sorted and stored, with seeds germinated over three to four years. During this period, many seeds will be graded and deemed infertile, with an estimated 600,000 saplings expected to be produced.

These young trees will ultimately establish new oak woods and enrich woodland habitats throughout the Galloway Forest Park, contributing to regional ecological restoration and biodiversity.

In a speech at an event in Berlin, Mark Carney highlighted the critical role of green finance in promoting financial stability, particularly in emerging markets. He argued that while capital should theoretically flow from advanced to emerging economies due to higher returns, the opposite has occurred, driving down bond yields in advanced economies. Carney emphasized that sporadic capital flows to emerging economies have been destabilizing, and proposed green finance as a strategic solution. He advocated for increased issuance of green bonds—such as those financing water or renewable power projects—noting their potential to double from $42 billion in 2015, despite currently representing only 1% of global financial institutional holdings. Carney underscored the complex challenge of addressing climate change, warning that by the time a clear economic incentive emerges, it may be too late to act effectively. He also cautioned that an overly rapid transition to a low-carbon economy could potentially damage financial stability. To mitigate these risks, Carney urged companies to disclose the financial risks posed by climate change to their business models, reiterating his previous warnings about the potential unrecoverability of fossil fuel reserves as governments pursue global warming limitations.

Gene Palmer, the second prison worker detained in connection with the jail break, is now under scrutiny following Joyce Mitchell's prior arrest for aiding the escape. Convicted killers Richard Matt and David Sweat utilized power tools to flee the Clinton Correctional Facility, prompting an extensive manhunt. Palmer has been released on bail after facing charges of promoting prison contraband, tampering with physical evidence, and official misconduct. His attorney, Andrew Brockway, acknowledged that Palmer delivered meat to the inmates but claimed his client was unaware it contained escape tools. District Attorney Andrew Wylie revealed that Mitchell had concealed hacksaw blades and other tools inside the meat, which Palmer subsequently delivered to Matt and Sweat in a section of the jail permitting inmates to prepare their own meals. Law enforcement is currently concentrating search efforts on a 75 sq mi (194 sq km) area in northern New York state, where evidence suggests the fugitives spent time at a hunting cabin near the prison. Given the region's abundant weaponry, authorities believe the escapees may be armed and consider them extremely dangerous and cunning.

The party's election manifesto proposed introducing a funding floor only after a referendum. The St David's Day Agreement had described the vote as an "expectation", with Labour Welsh ministers opposing a referendum prior to a funding agreement. Labour criticized the Conservatives for attempting to leverage their position. The manifesto explicitly stated that Conservatives would "introduce a 'funding floor' to protect Welsh relative funding and provide certainty for the Welsh Government to plan for the future, contingent upon calling a referendum on Income Tax powers in the next Parliament".

A Welsh Conservative spokeswoman clarified to BBC Wales that their commitment to a funding floor remains firm, with active work underway at the Treasury and Wales Office. She emphasized that the funding floor is not dependent on an income tax referendum, and that their expectation is for the Welsh Assembly to hold a referendum on income tax powers early in the next Parliament.

Chancellor George Osborne indicated the proposed funding floor would range between £113 and £116 per head for every £100 spent in England, aligning with economist Gerry Holtham's recommendations. Labour has similarly pledged to introduce a funding floor but has not specified a precise figure.

First Minister Carwyn Jones criticized the Conservative approach, stating that voting for the Tories could cost Wales up to £300m annually. He argued that a fair funding settlement should be unconditional. The Liberal Democrats proposed an independent review of funding arrangements, while Plaid Cymru advocated for an additional £1.2bn annual allocation. UKIP suggested scrapping the existing Barnett formula entirely.

In the crucible of European competition, Hibs and Glasgow City battled against formidable opponents, their spirits undaunted by scorelines that spoke of uneven contests. Bayern Munich's surgical precision overwhelmed Hibs 10-1 on aggregate, while City encountered resilient resistance from Eskilstuna United. Yet Anna Signeul's voice rang with pride, celebrating Scottish football's ascendance—two teams gracing the Champions League stage, a testament to years of dedicated craft and collective aspiration. The journey revealed stark contrasts: Bayern's professional ensemble, replete with Olympic talents and national squad players, stood as a beacon of excellence against which Scottish teams could measure their potential. Though the results were unforgiving, Signeul saw opportunity in adversity—a chance for young players to glimpse the summit of their ambitions, to understand the rarefied air of elite competition. Her perspective transcended immediate outcomes, focusing instead on growth, learning, and the incremental path to international recognition. In this narrative of sporting endeavor, defeat was not an endpoint, but a milestone on a longer, more profound journey of development and dreams.

The emergence of dockless bike-sharing represents a potential shift in urban transportation, with oBike launching its service in London this week. Backed by significant venture capital, the company has introduced hundreds of GPS-enabled bicycles that can be left anywhere using a rear-wheel locking mechanism. Users access bikes through a mobile app, paying a £49 refundable deposit and 50p per half-hour. While oBike aims to complement existing cycle hire schemes and reduce urban emissions, the launch has sparked controversy among local councils. Hackney and Hammersmith & Fulham councils have expressed concerns about bikes obstructing pavements and roads, criticizing the lack of prior consultation. London's Walking and Cycling Commissioner, Will Norman, emphasized the need for dock-less bike operators to collaborate with Transport for London and borough councils to ensure the schemes benefit all Londoners without negatively impacting road users and pedestrians. This scenario highlights the ongoing tension between innovative technology companies and municipal authorities in managing urban mobility solutions.

The Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee selected Gabon as the host nation on Wednesday, prevailing over rival candidates Ghana and Algeria. Jean-Felix Mba Nze, a Gabonese football official, affirmed the nation's commitment, stating, "We will prepare ourselves to win the Nations Cup in 2017." Having first entered the Nations Cup in 1970 and qualifying for the finals in 1994, Gabon's most notable achievements include quarter-final appearances in 1996 and 2012, the latter of which was co-hosted with Equatorial Guinea. Following their early elimination in the most recent tournament, Gabon is poised to host the 2017 Nations Cup independently. Mba Nze, the secretary general of the Gabonese federation, emphasized their strategic preparation, noting, "Our main challenge is to organize a superior competition compared to 2012." The nation will utilize two stadiums from the previous finals in Libreville and Franceville, supplemented by new venues in Port Gentil and Oyem, both scheduled for completion by August 2016. The selection was met with considerable controversy, with Algerian media expressing significant disappointment and the Ghanaian bid requesting greater transparency in the selection process. The Confederation of African Football defended its decision by referencing its established protocol for host country announcements.

In the vibrant landscape of British music festivals, a passionate tribe of "superfans" emerges, investing an average of £581 annually in their sonic pilgrimages. Predominantly male, these devotees transcend casual consumption, often selecting VIP experiences and embracing immersive musical journeys. A comprehensive survey of 504 UK residents reveals their profound cultural commitment: they champion music through recommendations, represent 28% of festival attendees, and display remarkable independence, with 54% willing to venture solo into the sonic wilderness. Their financial investment reflects their dedication, spending £45 more per event than casual listeners, though their loyalty remains nuanced—46% critique the growing corporate homogeneity of these musical gatherings. With over 100 festivals dotting the British landscape, from the legendary Glastonbury to intimate jazz celebrations, 3.7 million passionate music lovers annually fuel an ecosystem supporting 39,000 full-time jobs. Despite challenges of unpredictable weather, economic fluctuations, and market saturation, the spirit of festival culture endures. Remarkably, 88% of enthusiasts anticipate returning next year, signaling an unbreakable connection between audience and experience—a testament to the resilient, transformative power of live music.

In a shocking weekend, Cromer was rocked by 37 reported crimes, including the traumatic rape of a teenager, with residents directly linking these incidents to a group of travellers. Suffolk Constabulary had proactively warned Norfolk Police about the group's arrival on Friday, with Norfolk acknowledging the notification but claiming "no intelligence" about the group's destination. The grave situation escalated when a late-teen woman was sexually assaulted at a bus stop near the seafront, with police suggesting a potential connection to broader town disturbances. One suspect was arrested and subsequently released under investigation. Local businesses and residents painted a harrowing picture of the group's impact, with a taxi driver describing "travellers rampaging the town" and The Wellington pub closing after a rowdy group of 30 descended. Eyewitness accounts from business owners like Lee Sale and Ayrun Nessa detailed intimidating and aggressive behaviors that left families and community members feeling vulnerable. In response, Cromer's Safer Neighbourhood Team has initiated police surgeries to address community concerns. The group, comprising up to 25 caravans, arrived at the Runton Road cliff-top car park on Friday before moving on, leaving a community shaken and seeking answers.

In the azure expanse above Brookmans Park, a phantom quadcopter sliced through the silence, its white form a fleeting apparition that brushed perilously close to an A320's path. The pilot's heart raced as the drone flashed past, a spectral encounter where mere seconds separated safety from catastrophe. Air traffic control echoed the near-miss, a whispered testament to chance's delicate intervention. Crimson and azure stripes adorned the rotor arms of this diminutive intruder, invisible yet menacing, its presence a stark violation of aviation's sacred protocols. Unseen and untraceable, the drone operator remained a phantom, dancing beyond the boundaries of regulation, challenging the invisible threads of aerial safety. In that moment suspended between sky and potential disaster, the fragile balance of human technology and aerial navigation trembled, a silent reminder of the razor's edge between order and chaos.

A survey revealed a stark reality: a quarter of new fathers take no paternity leave at all, with fewer than one in 10 using more than their two statutory weeks. The Institute of Leadership & Management blamed this on deeply rooted employer attitudes and fathers' financial concerns. While the government plans to allow parents to share maternity and paternity leave starting in April 2015, the ILM warns these changes might fall flat without addressing workplace culture.

Charles Elvin, ILM's chief executive, highlighted the persistent expectation that women, not men, will step back from work. The report exposed another barrier: low paternity pay. Just 9% of surveyed fathers receive full pay beyond two weeks. Frances O'Grady from the TUC echoed this, noting that many dads simply can't afford time off.

Currently, fathers get one or two weeks' paid leave, with potential additional time if the mother returns to work. The government's upcoming changes aim to create more flexibility, hoping to drive a cultural shift that enables working dads to be more involved in their children's early months and helps retain talented women in the workforce.

As with last year's parade, only the Orangemen and their 13 notified bands can march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in north Belfast. They must do so to the sound of a single drum beat, with all music stopping 43 metres away from the church to ensure no music is within earshot. A planned residents' protest has been restricted to a maximum of 50 people at two locations. The Orange Order expressed strong opposition, stating the commission has become "a mouthpiece for republican propaganda" and is "censoring Protestant heritage" through "invented and absurd" criteria. North Belfast MP Nigel Dodds of the DUP criticised the determination as a "bureaucratic monstrosity" that capitulates to republican residents. In contrast, SDLP assembly member Alban Maginness welcomed the ruling, describing it as sensible and hoping it would set a respectful tone for the marching season. He noted that the parishioners of St Patrick's and Carrick Hill residents have consistently sought fair treatment.

The 34-year-old midfielder has just finished his latest spell in the Indian Super League with Atletico Kolkata. "Having been the player who has come back three times before, I know the appeal and why you would want to come back," said McFadden, who confirmed that Motherwell have made him an offer. "And I know Pearson is exactly the same." Pearson began his career at Fir Park and, after spells with Celtic, Derby County, Bristol City, and Kerala Blasters, rejoined Motherwell for a season in 2015. He is a free agent again after helping Kolkata finish fourth in the Indian league before winning the title with a play-off victory over his former club, Kerala. "We have spoken to him and offered him a deal and we're waiting to hear back," said McFadden, who thinks Motherwell have a tradition of welcoming back former players. "Pearson would be a great addition on and off the park here. We would love to have him back, so hopefully he makes the right decision and comes back. I know he has one or two things to think about before he makes that decision, but he knows he will be welcomed back with open arms here by everyone." Motherwell have signed winger Elliot Frear from Forest Green as well as adding Reading defender Zak Jules and Everton goalkeeper Russell Griffiths on loan in recent days. However, they are still looking to add to their squad before the transfer window closes. "There could be, we are still working away on that," added McFadden.
